questions.question_text: Which of the following is a well-defined collection of objects?

options.text: A collection of prime numbers less than 20

questions.explanation_correct: The collection of prime numbers less than 20 is a well-defined collection because prime numbers are a specific set of numbers that can be clearly identified and counted. This makes it a precise and definable set of objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not well-defined because they use subjective terms like 'beautiful' and 'intelligent' which can be interpreted differently by different people. 'Tall trees' is also not well-defined as there is no specific height that defines a tree as 'tall'. On the other hand, prime numbers less than 20 can be clearly listed and counted, making it a well-defined set.

questions.question_text: The collection of 'good students' is an example of a set.
questions.explanation_correct: The collection of 'good students' is not an example of a set because 'good students' is a subjective term and does not have a clear definition. A set must have a well-defined collection of elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The collection of 'good students' is not a set because the term 'good students' is not clearly defined. A set must have a precise and unambiguous description of its members. The term 'good' is subjective and can mean different things to different people, so it does not represent a well-defined set.

questions.question_text: If A = {2, 4, 6, 8}, then 6 _____ A. (Use the appropriate symbol)
questions.explanation_correct: The symbol '∈' means 'is an element of'. Since 6 is one of the numbers in the set A = {2, 4, 6, 8}, we can say that 6 'is an element of' the set A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The symbol '=' means 'is equal to', which is not the correct symbol to use in this case. The symbol '∈' should be used because it indicates that 6 is a member or element of the set A. The correct answer is '∈' because 6 is one of the numbers that belongs to the set A.

questions.question_text: The set A = {x : x is a natural number less than 5} in roster form is:
questions.explanation_correct: The set A = {x : x is a natural number less than 5} means the set contains all the natural numbers from 1 to 4. Since 0 is not a natural number, it is not included. Therefore, the correct answer is {1, 2, 3, 4}.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A, {0, 1, 2, 3, 4}, is incorrect because 0 is not a natural number. Option C, {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}, is incorrect because 5 is greater than the given condition of 'less than 5'. Option D, {2, 3, 4}, is incorrect because it does not include all the natural numbers less than 5.

questions.question_text: The set {2, 4, 6, 8, 10} in set-builder form is:

options.text: {x : x is an even natural number less than 12}

questions.explanation_correct: The set {2, 4, 6, 8, 10} can be represented in set-builder form as {x : x = 2n, where n ∈ {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}}. This means that the set contains all the values of x which are equal to 2 multiplied by some natural number between 1 and 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option D is the correct answer because the set {2, 4, 6, 8, 10} contains all the even numbers from 2 to 10. This set can be represented in set-builder form as {x : x = 2n, where n ∈ {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}}. The other options do not accurately describe this set. Option A is too broad, as it includes all even numbers, not just the ones in the given set. Option B is too specific, as it only includes even natural numbers less than 12. Option C is also too broad, as it includes all multiples of 2, not just the ones in the given set.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an empty set?

options.text: {x : x is a whole number less than 0}
{x : x is an odd number divisible by 2}

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is D. Both B and C represent empty sets. B describes the set of whole numbers less than 0, which does not exist, and C describes the set of odd numbers divisible by 2, which is also an impossible set.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A, {0}, is not an empty set. 0 is a whole number, so {0} represents the set containing just the number 0. Option B and C, however, do represent empty sets. An empty set is a set that contains no elements at all.

questions.question_text: A singleton set contains exactly one element.
questions.explanation_correct: A singleton set is a set that contains exactly one element. This means that a singleton set has only one member or element in it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A common misconception is that a set with multiple elements cannot be a singleton set. This is not true. A set can have any number of elements, and a singleton set is a special case where the set has exactly one element. The key is that a singleton set contains precisely one element, no more and no less.

questions.question_text: The set of natural numbers is a _____ set. (finite/infinite)
questions.explanation_correct: The set of natural numbers is an infinite set because the numbers go on forever. You can always find the next natural number by adding 1 to the previous one, so the set never ends.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The set of natural numbers is not a finite set. A finite set has a specific number of elements that can be counted. But the natural numbers (1, 2, 3, 4, and so on) keep going on forever, so the set is infinite. The correct answer is 'infinite'.

options.text: A and B are equal sets
A and B are not equal
A is a subset of B but not equal
B is a subset of A but not equal

questions.explanation_correct: The sets A and B are equal because they contain the same elements, even though the order of the elements is different. Since the elements in both sets are the same, they are considered equal sets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sets A and B are not equal because the order of the elements is different. However, this does not matter when comparing sets. The sets A and B are equal because they contain the same elements, even though the order is different. Sets are compared based on their contents, not the order of the elements.

questions.question_text: If 5 ∉ A, then:

options.text: 5 is not an element of A

questions.explanation_correct: If 5 is not an element of set A, it means 5 is not included in the set A. This is represented by the symbol '∉', which means 'not an element of'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because if 5 is not an element of set A, it means 5 is not included in the set. Option C is incorrect because 5 being not an element of A does not mean that 5 is a subset of A. Option D is incorrect because the fact that 5 is not an element of A does not necessarily mean that set A is empty.

options.text: A and B have no relation

questions.explanation_correct: The set A = {1, 2, 3} is a subset of the set B = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} because all the elements in A are also present in B. This means that A is contained within B, so A is a subset of B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The option B) B ⊆ A is incorrect because the set B = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} is not a subset of the set A = {1, 2, 3}. This is because B has more elements than A, and not all the elements in B are present in A. For a set to be a subset, all its elements must be present in the other set.

questions.question_text: Every set is a subset of itself.
questions.explanation_correct: Every set is a subset of itself because a set contains all the elements that belong to it. This means that all the elements in a set are also part of the set itself, making the set a subset of itself.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The common misconception is that a set cannot be a subset of itself. However, this is not true. A set is always a subset of itself because a subset is a collection of elements that are all part of the original set. Even though a set contains the same elements as itself, it is still considered a subset of itself.

questions.question_text: The empty set is a subset of _____ set.
questions.explanation_correct: The empty set (∅) is a subset of every set because it does not contain any elements. By definition, the empty set is a subset of any given set, since it does not have any elements that are not contained in the given set.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to say that the empty set is a subset of some set or a particular set. This is not correct because the empty set is a subset of every set, not just a specific set. The empty set is a special case in set theory, and it is considered a subset of all sets, regardless of what those sets contain.

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} because the union of two sets A and B includes all the unique elements that are present in either A or B or both. In this case, the union of A = {1, 2, 3, 4} and B = {3, 4, 5, 6} is all the numbers from 1 to 6.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. Option B) {3, 4} is incorrect because it only includes the common elements between A and B, but the union of sets should include all the unique elements from both sets. Option C) {1, 2, 5, 6} is also incorrect because it is missing the elements 3 and 4 which are present in both sets A and B. Option D) {1, 2, 3, 4, 3, 4, 5, 6} is incorrect because it includes duplicate elements 3 and 4.

questions.question_text: If A = {2, 4, 6, 8} and B = {4, 8, 12}, then A ∩ B is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) {4, 8} because the intersection (∩) of two sets A and B contains only the elements that are common to both sets. In this case, the elements that are present in both A = {2, 4, 6, 8} and B = {4, 8, 12} are 4 and 8.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) {4, 8}. Option A) {2, 4, 6, 8, 12} is incorrect because it includes elements from both sets A and B, but the intersection of two sets only includes the elements that are common to both sets. Option C) {2, 6} is incorrect because it only includes elements from set A, but not from set B. Option D) {12} is incorrect because 12 is not present in set A, so it cannot be in the intersection of A and B.

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) {1, 2, 3}. This is because A - B means all the elements that are in A but not in B. The elements 1, 2, and 3 are in A but not in B, so they make up the set A - B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) {1, 2, 3}. Option B) {4, 5} is incorrect because 4 and 5 are in both A and B, so they are not in the set A - B. Option C) {6} is incorrect because 6 is not in set A, so it cannot be in the set A - B. Option D) {1, 2, 3, 6} is incorrect because 6 is not in set A, so it should not be included in the set A - B.

questions.question_text: If n(A) = 15, n(B) = 10, and n(A ∩ B) = 5, then n(A ∪ B) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 20. The formula for the size of the union of two sets A and B is n(A ∪ B) = n(A) + n(B) - n(A ∩ B). Given that n(A) = 15, n(B) = 10, and n(A ∩ B) = 5, we can plug these values into the formula to get n(A ∪ B) = 15 + 10 - 5 = 20.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not follow the formula for the size of the union of two sets. Option A) 25 is incorrect because it does not account for the overlap between the two sets, which is represented by n(A ∩ B). Option C) 30 is incorrect because it is the sum of n(A) and n(B) without subtracting the overlap. Option D) 15 is incorrect because it is just the size of one of the sets, which does not represent the total size of the union.

questions.question_text: The roster form of the set {x : x is a vowel in the English alphabet} is _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The set of all vowels in the English alphabet is {a, e, i, o, u}. This is the roster form, which lists all the elements of the set.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The roster form of a set lists all the elements of the set. In this case, the set consists of all the vowels in the English alphabet, which are a, e, i, o, and u. The correct answer is {a, e, i, o, u}. The set does not include any other letters besides the vowels.

questions.question_text: The set {0} is an empty set.
questions.explanation_correct: The set {0} is not an empty set. It is a set that contains the single element 0, which is a number. The empty set is represented by the symbol ∅ and contains no elements at all.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The set {0} is not an empty set. The empty set, represented by the symbol ∅, does not contain any elements. However, the set {0} contains the single element 0, which is a number. Therefore, the statement 'The set {0} is an empty set' is false.

questions.question_text: If A ∩ B = ∅, then A and B are called disjoint sets.
questions.explanation_correct: When the intersection (overlap) between two sets A and B is an empty set (∅), it means they have no common elements. In this case, we say that A and B are disjoint sets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the intersection of two sets A and B is not empty, it means they have some common elements. However, if the intersection is an empty set (∅), it implies that A and B have no common elements. This is what we call disjoint sets.

questions.explanation_correct: If the total number of elements in set A is 20, the total number of elements in set B is 25, and the total number of elements in the union of A and B is 35, then the number of elements in the intersection of A and B must be 10. This is because the elements in the intersection are common to both sets A and B, and the total number of unique elements in A and B is 35, which means the number of elements in the intersection is 20 + 25 - 35 = 10.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to assume that the number of elements in the intersection of A and B is 15. This is because the total number of elements in A and B is 45 (20 + 25), and the total number of elements in the union of A and B is 35. However, this is not correct, as the number of elements in the intersection is 10, which is calculated by subtracting the total number of elements in the union from the sum of the elements in A and B.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to convert a set from roster form to set-builder form in the correct order:
ordering_items: Identify the common property of all elements
Write the general form using a variable
Specify the condition that defines the elements
correct_answer: Identify the common property of all elements
Write the general form using a variable
Specify the condition that defines the elements
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of steps to convert a set from roster form to set-builder form is: 1) Identify the common property of all elements, 2) Write the general form using a variable, 3) Specify the condition that defines the elements, and 4) Write in the form {x : condition}. This is because you first need to find the common characteristic shared by all the elements, then represent that characteristic using a variable, and finally state the condition that the variable must satisfy to be part of the set.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: 1) Write in the form {x : condition}, 2) Identify the common property of all elements, 3) Specify the condition that defines the elements, 4) Write the general form using a variable. This is wrong because you cannot write the set-builder form directly without first identifying the common property of the elements and using a variable to represent that property.

questions.question_text: How many subsets does the set {a, b, c} have?
questions.explanation_correct: The set {a, b, c} has 8 subsets. The 8 subsets are: the empty set {}, {a}, {b}, {c}, {a, b}, {a, c}, {b, c}, and {a, b, c}. This is because each element can either be included or excluded in a subset, leading to 2^3 = 8 possible subsets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The set {a, b, c} does not have 6, 7, or 9 subsets. To find the total number of subsets, we need to consider that each element can either be included or excluded in a subset. With 3 elements, there are 2^3 = 8 possible subsets. Therefore, the correct answer is 8 subsets.

questions.question_text: Which of the following represents a finite set?

options.text: Set of all points on a line
Set of students in your class

questions.explanation_correct: The set of students in your class is a finite set because the number of students in a class is limited and can be counted. In contrast, the set of all natural numbers or the set of all even numbers are infinite sets, as they have no end.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The set of all natural numbers, the set of all points on a line, and the set of all even numbers are all infinite sets, meaning they have no end and the number of elements in these sets cannot be counted. Only the set of students in your class is a finite set, as the number of students in a class is limited and can be counted.

questions.question_text: In a Venn diagram, the overlapping region of two circles representing sets A and B represents:
questions.explanation_correct: The overlapping region of two circles in a Venn diagram represents the intersection of the two sets, which is denoted as A ∩ B. This is the set of elements that are common to both sets A and B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) A ∩ B, which represents the elements that are common to both sets A and B. The other options are not correct because A ∪ B represents the union of the two sets, A - B represents the elements in A but not in B, and B - A represents the elements in B but not in A. The overlapping region in the Venn diagram specifically shows the intersection of the two sets, A ∩ B.

questions.question_text: The universal set is denoted by the symbol _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The universal set is denoted by the symbol 'U' because it represents the complete set of all elements being considered in a particular problem or situation. The universal set contains all the elements that are relevant to the topic or problem at hand.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The universal set is not denoted by the symbol 'X' or any other letter. The accepted answer format for the universal set symbol is simply 'U'. This is the standard notation used in mathematics to represent the universal set, which includes all the elements being considered in a given problem or context.

questions.question_text: A ∪ B = B ∪ A for any two sets A and B.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement 'A ∪ B = B ∪ A' is true because the union of two sets is a set that contains all the elements that are in either set A or set B, or in both sets. The order in which the sets are combined does not matter, so the result is the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'A ∪ B = B ∪ A' is not true. This is because the order in which the sets are combined does matter. The union of set A and set B is different from the union of set B and set A. The elements in the two unions may be the same, but the order in which they are listed is different.

questions.question_text: If A ⊆ B and B ⊆ A, then A = B.
questions.explanation_correct: If set A is a subset of set B, and set B is also a subset of set A, then the two sets must be equal. This means that the elements in set A and set B are exactly the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If set A is a subset of set B, it means that all the elements in set A are also present in set B. However, set B may have additional elements that are not in set A. Similarly, if set B is a subset of set A, it means that all the elements in set B are also present in set A. But set A may have additional elements that are not in set B. Therefore, for the sets to be equal, the elements in both sets must be exactly the same.

questions.question_text: In a class of 40 students, 25 like cricket and 20 like football. If 10 students like both sports, how many students like neither cricket nor football?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 5. This is because the total number of students in the class is 40, and 25 like cricket, 20 like football, and 10 like both. Subtracting the number of students who like either cricket or football (25 + 20 - 10 = 35) from the total number of students (40), we get 5 students who like neither cricket nor football.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is C) 15. This is because the question states that 25 students like cricket and 20 students like football, with 10 students liking both sports. The number of students who like neither cricket nor football is found by subtracting the number of students who like either sport from the total number of students in the class, which is 40 - (25 + 20 - 10) = 5 students.

questions.question_text: The set {x : x is an integer and −3 < x < 3} in roster form is:
questions.explanation_correct: The set {x : x is an integer and −3 < x < 3} represents all the integers between -3 and 3, excluding -3 and 3. So, the correct set in roster form is {-2, -1, 0, 1, 2}.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is the correct answer because the set {x : x is an integer and −3 < x < 3} represents all the integers between -3 and 3, excluding -3 and 3. The other options include either too many or too few elements compared to the given set.

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is ∅ (the empty set) because the intersection of two sets A and B means the set of all elements that are common to both A and B. Since there are no common elements between A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {4, 5, 6}, the intersection is empty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to fill in a set of numbers, such as {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. This is wrong because the intersection of two sets A and B means the set of all elements that are common to both A and B. Since there are no common elements between A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {4, 5, 6}, the correct answer is the empty set, ∅.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following in order from smallest to largest based on the number of elements: A = {1, 2}, B = {1}, C = {1, 2, 3, 4}, D = ∅
questions.explanation_correct: The set D, which is an empty set, has the smallest number of elements (0). The set B has 1 element, the set A has 2 elements, and the set C has the largest number of elements (4). Therefore, the correct order from smallest to largest is D, B, A, C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to arrange the sets based on the highest number in each set. This is not the correct way to order the sets. The number of elements in each set is what determines the order from smallest to largest, not the largest number in the set.

questions.question_text: If A = {1, 2} and B = {1, 2, 3}, then the number of proper subsets of A is _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The number of proper subsets of a set with n elements is 2^n - 1. Since set A has 2 elements, the number of proper subsets of A is 2^2 - 1 = 4 - 1 = 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a single number. The incorrect answer would be to list out all the subsets, which is not necessary. The correct number of proper subsets of set A = {1, 2} is 3, which are: {}, {1}, and {2}.

questions.question_text: If A = {x, y, z} and B = {y, z, w}, then (A − B) ∪ (B − A) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) {x, w}. This is because (A - B) contains the elements that are in A but not in B, which is just x. And (B - A) contains the elements that are in B but not in A, which is just w. So the union of these two sets is {x, w}.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is B) {y, z}. This is not correct because (A - B) contains the elements that are in A but not in B, which is just x. And (B - A) contains the elements that are in B but not in A, which is just w. So the union of these two sets is {x, w}, not {y, z}.

questions.question_text: In a Venn diagram with two sets, the region outside both circles but inside the rectangle represents the universal set.
questions.explanation_correct: The region outside both circles but inside the rectangle represents the set of elements that are not in either of the two sets, but are part of the universal set. This is known as the complement of the two sets, not the universal set.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The universal set is the set that contains all the elements being considered in a problem. In a Venn diagram with two sets, the region outside both circles but inside the rectangle represents the elements that are not in either of the two sets, which is known as the complement of the two sets. The universal set is represented by the entire rectangle, not just the region outside the two circles.

questions.question_text: The set-builder form uses a _____ to represent the general element of the set.
questions.explanation_correct: The set-builder form uses a variable to represent the general element of the set. This allows you to describe the set by specifying the characteristics or properties that the elements must have, rather than listing out each individual element.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The set-builder form does not use a number or a word to represent the general element of the set. Instead, it uses a variable, such as 'x' or 'n', to represent the elements that belong to the set. The variable allows you to describe the set using a general rule or condition, rather than simply listing out all the elements.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs are equal sets?

options.text: A = {a, b, c} and B = {c, b, a}

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is D. Both B and C are equal sets. In set B, the elements are just arranged in a different order, but the set still contains the same elements as set A. In set C, the elements 1 and 2 appear multiple times, but a set only counts each element once, so the sets are still equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is A. Sets A and B are not equal because set B contains an extra element, 4, that set A does not have. For sets to be equal, they must have the same elements, even if the order is different.

questions.question_text: Given A = {1, 2, 3}, B = {2, 3, 4}, arrange the following from smallest to largest cardinality: A ∩ B, A − B, B − A, A ∪ B
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from smallest to largest cardinality is A - B, A ∩ B, B - A, A ∪ B. This is because A - B has the smallest number of elements, followed by A ∩ B which has the elements common to both A and B, then B - A with the elements in B but not in A, and finally A ∪ B which has all the elements in both A and B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to arrange the sets in the order A ∩ B, A - B, A ∪ B, B - A. This is wrong because A ∩ B has fewer elements than A - B, which is the set of elements in A but not in B. Similarly, A ∪ B has more elements than B - A, which is the set of elements in B but not in A.

questions.question_text: If n(A) = 30, n(B) = 40, and all elements of A are also in B, then n(A ∪ B) = _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Since all the elements of set A are also in set B, the union of A and B is just the same as set B. Therefore, the number of elements in the union of A and B, n(A ∪ B), is equal to the number of elements in set B, which is 40.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 70, which is the sum of the number of elements in set A (30) and set B (40). However, this is not correct because all the elements of set A are already included in set B. Therefore, the number of elements in the union of A and B is just the number of elements in set B, which is 40.

questions.question_text: If A is a proper subset of B, then A and B cannot be equal.
questions.explanation_correct: If A is a proper subset of B, it means that all the elements of A are also present in B, but B has at least one element that is not in A. This means that A and B cannot be equal, as they must have at least one element that is different.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think that if A is a subset of B, then A and B must be equal. However, this is not true. A proper subset means that A is a part of B, but B has at least one element that is not in A. Therefore, A and B cannot be equal if A is a proper subset of B.

questions.question_text: Which statement correctly uses set notation?
questions.explanation_correct: Option B is correct because the symbol '∈' means 'is an element of'. The statement '2 ∈ {1, 2, 3}' means that the number 2 is an element of the set {1, 2, 3}, which is true.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is not correct because the symbol '∈' should be used to indicate that a single element is part of a set, not a set within a set. Option C is not correct because the symbol '⊆' means 'is a subset of', and a single number cannot be a subset of a set. Option D is not correct because the symbol '⊆' means 'is a subset of', and the number 2 is an element of the set {1, 2, 3}, not a subset of it.

questions.question_text: If A ∪ B = A, then:
questions.explanation_correct: If A ∪ B = A, it means that all the elements in set B are already included in set A. This means that set B is a subset of set A, or B ⊆ A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. B ⊆ A does not mean that A ⊆ B, as the question statement tells us that A ∪ B = A, which means B is a subset of A. Similarly, A = B is not true in this case, as the question states that A ∪ B = A, which means A and B are not equal. Lastly, A ∩ B = ∅ is not correct, as the question does not give any information about the intersection of A and B.

questions.question_text: In a survey of 100 people, 60 read newspaper A, 50 read newspaper B, and 20 read both. How many people read at least one newspaper?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 90. This is because the total number of people who read at least one newspaper is the sum of the people who read newspaper A and the people who read newspaper B, minus the people who read both newspapers (to avoid double counting). 60 + 50 - 20 = 90 people.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not accurately represent the total number of people who read at least one newspaper. Option A) 110 is incorrect because it includes the people who read both newspapers twice. Option C) 70 is incorrect because it only counts the people who read newspaper A or newspaper B, but not the people who read both. Option D) 80 is incorrect because it does not account for the people who read both newspapers.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following sets in order of their cardinality (number of elements) from smallest to largest: P = {prime numbers less than 10}, V = {vowels in English}, D = {digits}, E = {even prime numbers}
questions.explanation_correct: The set E (even prime numbers) has the smallest number of elements, as the only even prime number is 2. The set V (vowels in English) has 5 elements, the set P (prime numbers less than 10) has 4 elements, and the set D (digits) has 10 elements. Therefore, the sets are arranged in order of increasing cardinality as E, V, P, D.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be D, P, V, E. This is because the set D (digits) has the most elements, followed by the set P (prime numbers less than 10), then the set V (vowels in English), and lastly the set E (even prime numbers). However, the correct order is E, V, P, D, as explained earlier.

questions.question_text: If A = {1, 2, 3, 4}, which of the following is NOT a subset of A?
questions.explanation_correct: The set {1, 5} is not a subset of A because 5 is not an element in the set A, which only contains the numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option D, {1, 5}, is not a subset of A because it contains the number 5, which is not part of the set A. A subset of a set must contain only elements that are also in the original set.

questions.question_text: If A and B are disjoint sets with n(A) = 12 and n(B) = 8, then n(A ∪ B) = _____.
questions.explanation_correct: If two sets A and B are disjoint, meaning they do not have any common elements, then the total number of elements in both sets combined is simply the sum of their individual sizes. In this case, with n(A) = 12 and n(B) = 8, the total number of elements in the union of A and B is 12 + 8 = 20.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 20. The question states that A and B are disjoint sets, which means they do not have any common elements. To find the number of elements in the union of A and B, we simply add the number of elements in A and the number of elements in B. Since n(A) = 12 and n(B) = 8, the total number of elements in the union A ∪ B is 12 + 8 = 20.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of ∈?
questions.explanation_correct: The symbol ∈ means 'belongs to' or 'is an element of'. So, when we write 'x ∈ A', it means that the element 'x' is a part of the set 'A'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The symbol ∈ does not mean 'is a subset of' (A), 'empty set' (C), or 'does not belong to' (D). It specifically indicates that the element on the left side is a member of the set on the right side.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of ∉?
questions.explanation_correct: The symbol '∉' means 'does not belong to'. It shows that a particular element is not a part of the given set.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The symbol '∈' means 'belongs to', which shows that an element is a part of the given set. The symbol '∉' is the opposite, indicating that the element does not belong to the set. Option B, 'belongs to', is incorrect because it describes the '∈' symbol, not '∉'.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of ⊆?
questions.explanation_correct: The symbol '⊆' means 'is a subset of'. This means that all the elements in one set are also present in the other set, even if the other set may have additional elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The symbol '⊆' does not mean 'belongs to' (option A), as that is represented by the symbol '∈'. It also does not represent an 'empty set' (option C) or 'does not belong to' (option D). The correct meaning is 'is a subset of', which means that all the elements in one set are also present in the other set, even if the other set may have additional elements.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of ∅?
questions.explanation_correct: The symbol ∅ represents the empty set, which is a set with no elements. This means that there are no items or objects in the set.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The option 'B) Empty set' is the correct answer. The symbol ∅ represents the empty set, which is a set with no elements. This means that there are no items or objects in the set. The other options, such as 'does not belong to' and 'belongs to', are not the correct meanings of the symbol ∅.

questions.question_text: What is the symbol/formula for Union?
questions.explanation_correct: The symbol ∪ is used to represent the union of two sets. The union of two sets A and B is the set of all elements that are in either A, B, or both. This is the correct symbol to use for the union operation in set theory.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The symbol ⊆ is used to represent the subset relationship, where set A is a subset of set B. The symbol - is used for the difference of two sets, where we take all the elements in one set that are not in the other set. The symbol ∩ is used to represent the intersection of two sets, which is the set of all elements that are common to both sets. None of these are the correct symbol for the union operation in set theory.

questions.question_text: What is the symbol/formula for Intersection?
questions.explanation_correct: The symbol '∩' is used to represent the intersection of two sets. The intersection of two sets A and B is the set of all elements that are common to both A and B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The symbol '-' is used for subtraction, not for intersection. The symbol '⊆' is used to represent the subset relationship, not the intersection. The symbol '∪' is used to represent the union of two sets, not the intersection. The correct symbol to represent the intersection of two sets is '∩'.

questions.question_text: What is the symbol/formula for Difference?
questions.explanation_correct: The symbol '-' represents the Difference between two sets. Difference is used to find all the elements that are in one set but not in the other set.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The symbol '∩' represents the Intersection between two sets, which gives the common elements between the sets. The symbol '⊆' represents the Subset, which checks if one set is a subset of another set. The symbol '∪' represents the Union between two sets, which gives all the unique elements from both sets.

questions.question_text: What is the symbol/formula for Subset?
questions.explanation_correct: The symbol ⊆ represents a subset. A subset is a set that is entirely contained within another set. This symbol means that the set on the left side is a subset of the set on the right side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The symbol - represents a set difference, which is used to find the elements that are in one set but not in another set. The symbol ∪ represents a union, which is used to combine two sets into one set. The symbol ∩ represents an intersection, which is used to find the common elements between two sets. The correct symbol for a subset is ⊆, as it shows that one set is a part of another set.

questions.question_text: What is the their types: of {x : x is a prime number greater than 2 and less than 3}?
questions.explanation_correct: The set {x : x is a prime number greater than 2 and less than 3} is an empty set because there are no prime numbers between 2 and 3. The only prime numbers in this range are 2 and 3, and the question specifically excludes 2, so the set is empty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The set {x : x is a prime number greater than 2 and less than 3} cannot be a finite set, an infinite set, or a singleton set. This is because there are no prime numbers between 2 and 3, so the set contains no elements at all. Therefore, the correct answer is that it is an empty set.

questions.question_text: What is the their types: of {2}?
questions.explanation_correct: The set {2} is a singleton set, which means it contains only one element. The set {2} is a finite set because it has a specific, countable number of elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The set {2} is not an infinite set because it has a specific, countable number of elements. It is also not an empty set, as it contains the element 2. The correct answer is that the set {2} is a singleton set, which means it contains only one element.

questions.question_text: What is the their types: of {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}?
questions.explanation_correct: The set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} is a finite set because it contains a specific and limited number of elements. A finite set has a definite number of elements that can be counted, as opposed to an infinite set which has no end.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} is not an infinite set because it has a specific number of elements that can be counted. It is also not an empty set, as it contains 5 elements. Similarly, it is not a singleton set, as it has more than one element.

questions.question_text: What is the their types: of {x : x is a whole number}?
questions.explanation_correct: The set {x : x is a whole number} is an infinite set because there are infinitely many whole numbers, such as 0, 1, 2, 3, and so on.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The set {x : x is a whole number} is not a singleton set because it contains more than one element. It is also not an empty set, as it contains all the whole numbers. Finally, it is not a finite set, as there are infinitely many whole numbers.

questions.question_text: What is the set-builder form: of {1, 3, 5, 7, 9}?

options.text: {x : x is an odd natural number less than 10}
{x : x is a whole number less than 4}
{x : x is an even natural number less than 10}

questions.explanation_correct: The set {1, 3, 5, 7, 9} consists of all the odd natural numbers less than 10, so the set-builder form is {x : x is an odd natural number less than 10}.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the set {1, 3, 5, 7, 9} does not consist of perfect squares. Option C is incorrect because the set {1, 3, 5, 7, 9} has more than 3 elements. Option D is incorrect because the set {1, 3, 5, 7, 9} consists of odd numbers, not even numbers.

questions.question_text: What is the set-builder form: of {2, 4, 6, 8}?

options.text: {x : x is a whole number less than 4}
{x : x is an odd natural number less than 10}
{x : x is an even natural number less than 10}

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is D because the set {2, 4, 6, 8} contains all the even natural numbers less than 10. The set-builder form {x : x is an even natural number less than 10} accurately describes this set.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because they do not accurately describe the given set. Option A is for numbers less than 4, Option B is for odd numbers less than 10, and Option C is for perfect squares, which do not match the given set of even numbers less than 10.

questions.question_text: What is the set-builder form: of {1, 4, 9, 16}?

options.text: {x : x is an even natural number less than 10}
{x : x is a whole number less than 4}
{x : x is an odd natural number less than 10}

questions.explanation_correct: The set-builder form {x : x = n², where n ∈ {1, 2, 3, 4}} correctly describes the given set {1, 4, 9, 16} because each number in the set is the square of a natural number between 1 and 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option D is the correct answer because the set {1, 4, 9, 16} can be described as the set of squares of natural numbers from 1 to 4. The other options do not accurately describe this set - option A includes even numbers less than 10, option B includes whole numbers less than 4, and option C includes odd numbers less than 10, which do not match the given set.

questions.question_text: What is the set-builder form: of {0, 1, 2, 3}?

options.text: {x : x is a whole number less than 4}
{x : x is an even natural number less than 10}
{x : x is an odd natural number less than 10}

questions.explanation_correct: The set-builder form '{x : x is a whole number less than 4}' correctly represents the set {0, 1, 2, 3} because it describes all the whole numbers from 0 up to, but not including, 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is incorrect because the set {x : x = n², where n ∈ {1, 2, 3, 4}} represents the perfect squares between 1 and 16, which is different from the set {0, 1, 2, 3}. Option C is incorrect because the set {x : x is an even natural number less than 10} includes the even numbers 2, 4, 6, and 8, which is a different set. Option D is incorrect because the set {x : x is an odd natural number less than 10} includes the odd numbers 1, 3, 5, 7, and 9, which is also a different set.
